item.title: Using NodeJS to automate a ci cd pipeline
item.description: This is how i used NodeJS to simulate github actions ci cd pipeline stpes. Main flow notice the use of console.time('label') Hereâ€¦
item.content:encoded:
This is how i used NodeJS to simulate github actions ci cd pipeline stpes.

Main flow notice the use of

console.time('label')

JS
;(async () => {
  console.log("Starting deployment...")
  console.time("Total deployment time")
  // clearWorkspaceDirectory()
  const report = await buildAndDeploy()
  // printReport(report)
  console.log("Deployment done.")
  console.timeEnd("Total deployment time")
})()

Here im iterating services and running my pipeline commands using Javascript this way makes it easy to run & debug the code strait from VSCode

JS
//buildAndDeploy implementation
for (var service of services) {
  try {
    await runStep(
      service,
      "clone",
      getCloneAndCheckoutScript(
        WORKSPACE_DIRECTORY,
        service,
        "simple-build" // TODO:!!! change to master when finish developing1!!
      )
    )
    await runStep(
      service,
      "tag",
      getTagScript(WORKSPACE_DIRECTORY, service, LGX_GIT_TAG)
    )
    //TODO: as an improvment this could be replaced with running inside docker container
    const serviceDirectory = `${WORKSPACE_DIRECTORY}/${service}`
    await runStep(
      service,
      "build",
      `cd ${serviceDirectory} && ./simple-build/build.sh`
    )
    await runStep(
      service,
      "storeArtifact",
      `WORKSPACE_DIRECTORY=${WORKSPACE_DIRECTORY} LAWGEEX_SERVICE_NAME=${service} LGX_GIT_TAG=${LGX_GIT_TAG} ./frontends-build-and-deploy/push-artifact.sh`
    )
    await runStep(
      service,
      "deploy and invalidate cache",
      `cd ${serviceDirectory} && LGX_ENV=${LGX_ENV} node ./simple-build/deploy.js`
    )
    report[service] = { status: "success" }
  } catch (err) {
    report[service] = { status: "fail", msg: err.msg }
  }
}
return report

Example usage of

Spawn
to create a new child process

JS
const runStep = async (service, step, pipelineCommands) => {
  console.log(`\n---- STEP : ${step} ----\n`)
  console.time(`step - ${step}`)
  return new Promise((resolve, reject) => {
    const proc = spawn(pipelineCommands, [], { shell: true })
    logProgress(proc, service)
    proc.on("close", code => {
      if (code === 0) {
        console.timeEnd(`step - ${step}`)
        resolve()
      }
      if (code !== 0) {
        console.error(
          `${service} build encountered an error, child process exited with code ${code}`
        )
        reject({ service, status: "fail", msg: "failed to " + step })
      }
    })
  })
}
const logProgress = (proc, service) => {
    // console output will output here
    proc.stdout.on('data', (data) => {
        console.log(`${service}: ${data}`)
    })
    proc.stderr.on('data', (data) => {
        console.log(`${service}: ${data}`)
    })
    proc.on('error', (error) => {
        console.error(`${service} error: ${error.message}`)
    })
}

item.title: Creating an Angular app CI/CD pipeline with Github Actions & Firebase â€” (~5min setup)
item.content:encoded:
1. create angular app using the angular-cli ng new play-with-github-actions
  2. add firebaserc & firebase.json files to the root of the project
  3. add to root folder github/workflows/main.yml
JSON
// .firebaserc
{
  "projects": {
    "default": "liranmeir-actions"
  }
}
JSON
// firebase.json
{
  "hosting": {
    "public": "dist/play-with-github-actions",
    "ignore": ["firebase.json", "**/.*", "**/node_modules/**"],
    "rewrites": [
      {
        "source": "**",
        "destination": "/index.html"
      }
    ]
  }
}
YAML
#  main.yml
name: CI-CD
# Controls when the action will run. Triggers the workflow on push or pull request
# events but only for the master branch
on:
  push:
    branches: [master]
  pull_request:
    branches: [master]
# A workflow run is made up of one or more jobs that can run sequentially or in parallel
jobs:
  # This workflow contains a single job called "build"
  build:
    # The type of runner that the job will run on
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    # Steps represent a sequence of tasks that will be executed as part of the job
    steps:
      # Checks-out your repository under $GITHUB_WORKSPACE, so your job can access it
      - uses: actions/checkout@v2
      - name: Use Node.js ${{ matrix.node-version }}
        uses: actions/setup-node@v1
        with:
          node-version: 12.x
      - name: install dependencies
        run: npm install
      - name: build
        run: npm run build
      - name: test
        run: npm run test-headless
      - name: Archive Production Artifact
        uses: actions/upload-artifact@master
        with:
          name: dist
          path: dist/play-with-github-actions
  deploy:
    name: Deploy
    needs: build
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout Repo
        uses: actions/checkout@master
      - name: Download Artifact
        uses: actions/download-artifact@master
        with:
          name: dist
          path: dist/play-with-github-actions
      - name: Deploy to Firebase
        uses: w9jds/firebase-action@master
        with:
          args: deploy --only hosting
        env:
          FIREBASE_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.FIREBASE_TOKEN }}
  1. in the terminal hit firebase login:ci
  2. then copy the FIREBASE_TOKEN and store it in your GitHub repoâ€™s settings>Secrets section
  3. Trigger a push/pull request and witness the pipeline being automated â€¦ Boom!!!

item.title: Setup multiple Github users work & private
item.description: work with github personal and work accounts
item.content:encoded:
Follow below instructions to setup both work and personal git acconts

1. First thing will be to Create ssh key for both accounts

ssh-keygen -t rsa -C "liran.m@lawgeex.com" -f â€œgithub-lawgeex" ssh-keygen -t rsa -C "liran.meir@gmail.com" -f â€œgithub-liranmeir"

2. create ~/ssh/config and paste the following

~/SSH/CONFIG
#Host *
#  AddKeysToAgent yes
#  UseKeychain yes
#  IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_rsa
#lirameir account
Host github.com
HostName github.com
User git
IdentityFile ~/.ssh/github-liranmeir
#lawgeex account
Host github.com-liranmeirlawgeex
HostName github.com
User git
IdentityFile ~/.ssh/github-lawgeex

3. add these to the agent via terminal:

TEXT
ssh-add -K ~/.ssh/github-liranmeir
ssh-add -K ~/.ssh/github-lawgeex

3.1 login to github.com first with personal user and then work user

and copy secretes to both github accounts :

TEXT
>pbcopy < ~/.ssh/github-liranmeir.pub
>pbcopy < ~/.ssh/github-lawgeex.pub

4. set default git user name

TEXT
git config â€” global user.name "liranmeir"
git config â€” global user.email "liranmeirgmail.com"
inside of every new repo youâ€™ll need to set the default user (work/personal) by using this command:

git config user.email "liranmeir@lawgeex.com"
